title: 112_hr4265
content: The Act is titled the "Shared Responsibility in Preserving America's Future Act" and includes a surtax on millionaires contingent on the passage of a balanced budget amendment or spending limit amendment. This surtax is added as a new part to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Shared Responsibility in Preserving America's Future Act" includes a surtax on taxpayers with modified adjusted gross income exceeding $1,000,000 for taxable years between 2012 and 2023. The surtax is set at 5 percent of the income exceeding the threshold amount. The threshold amount for the surtax on taxpayers with income over $1,000,000 is subject to inflation adjustments starting from 2013. The threshold amount for the surtax on taxpayers with income over $1,000,000 is subject to inflation adjustments starting from 2013, with paragraph (1) being increased by an amount determined by the cost-of-living adjustment for the relevant calendar year. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $10,000, it will be rounded up to the next highest multiple. The threshold amount for the surtax on taxpayers with income over $1,000,000 is adjusted annually based on inflation. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $10,000, it will be rounded up to the next highest multiple. For married individuals filing separately, the threshold amount is half of the standard threshold. The threshold amount for the surtax on taxpayers with income over $1,000,000 is adjusted annually based on inflation. For married individuals filing separately, the threshold amount is half of the standard threshold. Modified adjusted gross income is calculated by reducing adjusted gross income by the excess of gross income from a trade or business. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is defined as adjusted gross income reduced by the excess of gross income from a trade or business that is not a passive activity with respect to the taxpayer and for which the taxpayer pays wages to at least 1 full-time equivalent employee. The Secretary will prescribe regulations similar to section 469(l) for determining the income considered for tax purposes. The Secretary will prescribe regulations similar to section 469(l) for determining the income considered for tax purposes, including deductions properly allocable to such income. Special rules apply for nonresident alien individuals and citizens/residents living abroad. Special rules apply for nonresident alien individuals and citizens/residents living abroad regarding the amounts taken into account for tax purposes. The amount under subsection (a) is reduced by the excess of amounts excluded from gross income under section 911 over deductions disallowed under section 911(d)(6). Charitable trusts are exempt from subsection (a) if all interests are for charitable purposes. The tax imposed under this section is not considered tax imposed by this chapter for certain purposes, such as determining credits or for section 55. The tax imposed under this section is not considered tax imposed by this chapter for determining credits or for section 55. Application of Section Contingent on Balanced Budget or Spending Limit Amendment. This section shall not apply to any taxable year before the President certifies the submission of a proposed amendment to the Constitution for ratification by the States. If the President does not certify the submission of a proposed amendment to the Constitution by September 30, 2012, this section will not apply to any taxable year. The section applies to proposed spending limit amendments to the Constitution of the United States. If the President does not certify the amendment by September 30, 2012, it won't apply. The section will not apply after December 31, 2017, unless the amendment is ratified by then. The section applies to proposed spending limit amendments to the Constitution of the United States. If the President does not certify the amendment by September 30, 2012, it won't apply. This section shall not apply to any taxable year beginning after December 31, 2017, unless, on or before such date, such an amendment, by ratification, becomes valid to all intents and purposes as part of the Constitution of the United States. The amendment on the surtax for millionaires will not be considered a change in tax rate under section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012.
